For example, a comprehensive analysis published in the journal Energy found that coal results in around 0.02 deaths per TWh, while nuclear causes approximately 0.07 deaths per TWh. 

This means that for every trillion watts of electricity produced, coal power leads to 2 deaths on average, while nuclear power causes 7 deaths. Put simply, coal is over 3 times safer than nuclear when it comes to mortality rates.

When coal is burned, it releases a number of toxic pollutants into the air that can have severe health impacts. Here are some of the main ways coal pollution harms human health:

Particulate matter: Coal burning releases tiny particles (PM2.5) that can lodge deep in the lungs and enter the bloodstream. These particles are linked to increased rates of heart attacks, strokes, lung cancer, asthma, and other respiratory diseases. [1]

Mercury: Coal is the largest source of mercury emissions in the US. When inhaled, mercury damages the lungs and can also harm the brain, heart, kidneys, and immune system. Developing fetuses and young children are especially vulnerable. [2]

Sulfur dioxide (SO2): Coal power is a major source of SO2, which forms acid rain and particulate matter when it reacts with other compounds in the air. SO2 can cause respiratory issues and aggravate existing heart and lung conditions. [3]

Nitrogen oxides (NOx): Coal plants emit NOx, which contributes to the formation of smog and particulate matter. NOx exposure can impair lung function and increase susceptibility to respiratory infections. [4]

These pollutants don't just stay near the power plant - they can travel hundreds of miles and impact air quality regionally. The health impacts fall disproportionately on low-income communities and communities of color, who are more likely to live near coal plants. [5]

So in summary, the air pollution from burning coal contains a toxic stew of particles and chemicals that damage the lungs, heart, and other organs, leading to increased rates of chronic diseases and premature deaths. While coal power provides cheap electricity, the health costs to nearby communities are very high.

It's worth noting that modern pollution controls like scrubbers and baghouses can reduce some of these emissions. But even with controls, coal still emits far more pollution than natural gas or renewables. And retrofitting old plants with controls is expensive.

Ultimately, transitioning away from coal to cleaner energy sources is critical for reducing the health impacts of air pollution. Policies like the Clean Air Act have made a big difference, but there is still a lot of work to do to clean up the air and protect public health.
